questions.text: Multiple endocrine neoplasia (MEN) type 1 is also called as ___________ .
questions.solution:
MEN1 is also referred to as Wermer's syndrome.

Related Pearl: MEN 1 Syndrome Features

Chromosome 11q13 / MEN1 gene

Also known as Wermer’s syndrome

Characteristic tumors seen in:

  • Parathyroid adenoma – 90 % - Most common overall
  • Entero pancreatic tumors - Most common functioning tumor is gastrinoma (most common site is duodenum)
  • Pituitary adenoma – Most common is prolactinoma
  • Mnemonic – Par Pan Pit – in decreasing order of frequency

Associated tumors are:

  • Angiofibroma
  • Collagenomas
  • Adrenal cortical tumors
  • Lipoma
  • Neuroendocrine tumors - gastric, thymic, lungs
  • Meningioma
  • Pheochromocytoma
  • Carcinoid tumors, usually of the foregut

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is not observed in MEN1 syndrome?
questions.solution:
Anterior pituitary tumours are associated with MEN1 syndrome, not posterior pituitary tumors.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presented with abdominal pain, nausea, and diarrhea. He had a history of hyperparathyroidism and a transsphenoidal prolactinoma resection. Which of the following is the most common functional enteropancreatic tumor seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of MEN1 syndrome and gastrinoma is the most common functional enteropancreatic tumor in MEN1 / Wermer's syndrome. 

Enteropancreatic tumors in MEN1 syndrome are:

  • Non-functioning pancreatic tumors (most common overall)
  • Functioning pancreatic tumors :
    • Gastrinoma - 50% (most common among functioning pancreatic tumours)
    • Insulinoma - 30%
    • Glucagonoma
    • VIPoma (least common)

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common site of gastrinoma in MEN 1 syndrome?
questions.solution:
Most common site of gastrinoma in MEN 1 syndrome is the first and second part of duodenum.

MEN 1 syndrome is characterized by the triad of tumors involving the parathyroids, pancreatic islets, and anterior pituitary.

Gastrinoma is the most common pancreatic islet tumor in MEN 1 syndrome and if it is associated with marked gastric acid production and recurrent peptic ulcers, the condition is called Zollinger Ellison syndrome.

Related Pearl: Passaro’s Triangle

Around 90% of gastrinomas are found in this triangle.

Its boundaries are as follows:

  • Junction of the cystic duct and common bile duct
  • Junction of the 2nd and 3rd parts of the duodenum
  • Junction of the body and neck of the pancreas

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents to the OPD with complaints of recurrent episodes of weakness, headache, sweating, and fainting after fasting. He tells that the symptoms improve after the consumption of food.  There is a history of MEN1 syndrome running in the family. Serum C peptide levels are found to be elevated. What is the definitive treatment of choice in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with elevated serum C peptide levels points towards a diagnosis of insulinoma in a MEN1 patient. The definitive treatment of choice in this patient is surgery.

Insulinoma is the second most common functioning enteropancreatic tumor in MEN1 syndrome. Investigation of choice is 72-hour fasting glucose and serum insulin levels. These parameters are measured when the patient develops hypoglycemic symptoms during a supervised 72-hour fasting period.

The treatment of choice is surgery, ranging from enucleation of a single tumor to pancreatectomy.

Non-surgical management of insulinoma includes frequent consumption of carbohydrate-rich meals, octreotide or diazoxide, which are not always successful.

Selpercatinib, a kinase inhibitor was recently approved by the FDA. It is used to treat tumours with a mutation in the RET gene. These are non-small cell lung cancer, medullary thyroid cancer, and other types of thyroid cancers in patients with a mutation in the RET gene.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most frequently observed cutaneous manifestation of MEN1 syndrome?
questions.solution:
The most frequently observed cutaneous manifestation of MEN1 syndrome is angiofibroma.

Cutaneous tumors in MEN1 Syndrome are:

  • Angiofibroma – 85%
  • Collagenoma – 70%
  • Lipoma - 33%

questions.text: A 22-year-old man who was diagnosed with MEN1 syndrome presents to your OPD for his annual checkup. Which of the following investigations will you not do as part of annual screening for this patient?
questions.solution:
Secretin study is not done as an annual screening test in patients with MEN1 syndrome. It is a provocative test for the diagnosis of gastrinoma.

Annual biochemical screening tests to be done in patients with MEN1 syndrome are:

Tumor Age to begin screening Annual screening test
Parathyroid 8 Calcium, PTH
Gastrinoma 20 Gastrin (+/- gastric pH)
Insulinoma 5 Fasting glucose, insulin
Other pancreatic NETs <10 Chromogranin A; pancreatic polypeptide, glucagon,
vasoactive intestinal peptide
Anterior pituitary 5 Prolactin, IGF-I

Other imaging tests like MRI and CT might have to be done for screening of conditions like anterior pituitary tumors or adrenal tumors.

Related Pearl: Diagnostic tests in Zollinger Ellison Syndrome

To confirm the diagnosis of ZES,

  • Gastric pH <2.5 and
  • Serum gastrin >1000pg/ml (normal <100pg/ml)

Provocative tests can be done like the secretin stimulation test when the diagnosis is in doubt. An increase in serum gastrin >200pg/ml following an IV bolus of secretin (2U/kg) is diagnostic.

Other tests:

  • BAO >15mEq/h (or >5mEq/h if they have had a procedure for peptic ulcer)
  • BAO: MAO ratio is increased (>0.6)

(BAO=Basal acid output; MAO=Maximal acid output)

For localization

  • Initial investigation - CT or MRI
  • Best investigation - Endoscopic ultrasound
  • If the tumor is not localized - Somatostatin receptor scintigraphy.

questions.text: What is the most common component of Sipple’s syndrome?
questions.solution:
The most common component of MEN2A syndrome, which is also called Sipple’s syndrome is medullary thyroid cancer.

Related Pearl: MEN 2 Syndrome Features

MEN 2A

  • Known as Sipple’s syndrome
  • Chromosome 10 / RET gene
  • Associated conditions are:
    • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (90%)
    • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
    • Parathyroid adenoma (10–25%)

MEN 2B

  • Known commonly as MEN 3
  • Chromosome 10/ RET gene
  • Associated conditions are:
    • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (>90%)
    • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
    • Other associated abnormalities include: (40–50%)
      • Mucosal neuromas
      • Marfanoid habitus
      • Medullated corneal nerve fibers
      • Megacolon

questions.text: Which of the following features would you not expect to see in a patient with MEN2 syndrome?
questions.solution:
Pituitary adenoma is not a characteristic feature of the symptom complex of MEN2 and its variants, but it is observed in MEN1 and MEN4 syndrome.

questions.text: Which of the following features would you not expect to see in a patient with MEN2B syndrome?
questions.solution:
Meningioma is not commonly seen in MEN2B Syndrome. MEN1 syndrome is associated with meningiomas.

questions.text: MEN4 syndrome is caused by a mutation in which of the following genes?
questions.solution:
MEN4 is caused by genetic mutations in CDKN1B (cyclin-dependent kinase inhibitor), located on chromosome 12.

MEN1 is caused due to MEN1 gene mutation on chromosome 11.

MEN2 is associated with RET proto-oncogene mutation on chromosome 10.

Related Pearl: MEN 4 Syndrome Features

It is associated with CDKN1B gene on chromosome 12.

Associated conditions:

  • Parathyroid adenoma
  • Pituitary adenoma
  • Reproductive organ tumors like testicular cancer, neuroendocrine cervical carcinoma
  • Adrenal and renal tumors

questions.text: Which of the following malignancies would you not expect to see in a patient with MEN4 syndrome?
questions.solution:
Medullary thyroid carcinoma is not associated with MEN4 syndrome, but it is associated with MEN2 syndrome.

Related Pearl: MEN 4 Syndrome Features

It is associated with CDKN1B gene on chromosome 12.

questions.text: A patient presented with abdominal pain and swelling in his scrotum and was diagnosed to have testicular carcinoma. There is a history of MEN syndrome running in his family. Which of the following conditions is he likely to have?
questions.solution:
This patient is likely to have MEN4 syndrome as reproductive organ tumors are a characteristic feature of this condition.
